item.title: Modern American Opera Wouldn’t Be the Same Without Her
item.description: Beth Morrison has shepherded dozens of new works into existence over the past 20 years. And her footprint continues to grow.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.media:credit: Ye Fan for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I have made a career of finding like-minded people who have become the village it takes to make a real movement,” Beth Morrison said.

item.title: Paris Opera Names Semyon Bychkov as Its Next Musical Director
item.description: Semyon Bychkov will be the musical director for a period when the opera’s performance spaces are under renovation. It’s a chance to add symphonic seasons, like at La Scala.
item.dc:creator: Roslyn Sulcas
item.media:credit: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times
item.media:description: Semyon Bychkov conducting the New York Philharmonic in 2018.

item.title: Mickey Rourke Declines $100,000 in Donations After His Eviction
item.description: Rourke’s landlord said in court documents that the actor owed nearly $60,000 in rent. Rourke said he had opted not to pay rent after the home became uninhabitable.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: The actor Mickey Rourke in New York in 2019.

item.title: Béla Fleck Withdraws From Kennedy Center Concerts
item.description: “Performing there has become charged and political,” the 18-time Grammy winner said.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: Béla Fleck was scheduled to perform in three concerts next month with the National Symphony Orchestra.

item.title: Readers Pick the Songs That Defined Their 2025
item.description: Stories behind tracks by Fontaines D.C., Beyoncé, Nina Simone and more.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:description: Fontaines D.C.

item.title: Dance Moves From the Street, City Edition
item.description: Dancers from Detroit, Chicago and Philadelphia demonstrate the fundamentals of their styles, revealing deep historical roots.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert and Vincent Tullo
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

item.title: I’m New to Jazz. Where Do I Start?
item.description: A Gen Z reader wants to get into the genre but wonders, “Who should I listen to?”
item.dc:creator: David Renard

item.title: Georgian National Ballet Brings Country’s Folk Dance to New York
item.description: The Georgian National Ballet Sukhishvili brings its blazing version of the country’s folk dances to New York.
item.dc:creator: Marina Harss
item.media:credit: Daro Sulakauri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sukhishvili dancers rehearsing at the Georgian National Ballet studio in Tbilisi.

item.title: Critics Choice Awards 2026: The Complete Winners List
item.description: “One Battle After Another” won best picture, while the top acting honors went to Timothée Chalamet (“Marty Supreme”) and Jessie Buckley (“Hamnet”).
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:description: From left, Benicio del Toro, Leonardo DiCaprio, the casting director Cassandra Kulukundis, the director Paul Thomas Anderson and Chase Infiniti, accepting best picture for “One Battle After Another.”

item.title: Marina Viotti: The Opera Star With Heavy-Metal Chops
item.description: The busy mezzo-soprano Marina Viotti has made a career out of versatility: “I think generally people should not do only one thing in their lives.”
item.dc:creator: Roslyn Sulcas
item.media:credit: Djamila Grossman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marina Viotti in Zurich where she is singing Prince Orlofsky in “Die Fledermaus.”

item.title: $650,000 in Pop Star Memorabilia? These Superfans Know Few Limits.
item.description: For megafans of megastars like Madonna and Mariah Carey, obsessive collecting is an emotional, not a financial, investment. The tradition dates to ancient Rome.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Alice Zoo for The New York Times
item.media:description: By surrounding himself in Madonna memorabilia, James Harknett said, he felt “comforted and excited.”

item.title: Kevin O’Leary on ‘Marty Supreme’ and Notes He Gave Josh Safdie
item.description: When it came to his film acting debut, the“Shark Tank” investor had some notes for the director Josh Safdie.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:description: For the movie, O’Leary wore two watches, one on each wrist: one set to New York time, the other set to Tokyo time.

item.title: On ‘Best Medicine,’ Josh Charles Has a Heart
item.description: After years of playing smarmy characters, the actor is stepping up as the lead in a comedy about a grumpy but charming doctor.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Peter Fisher for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It’s been feast or famine,” the actor Josh Charles said of his career in movies, TV and theater. He added: “I just want to do good work.”

item.title: Rosa von Praunheim, 83, Dies; Captured Gay Life in Germany on Film
item.description: His first feature-length movie, in 1971, was called his country’s “Stonewall moment,” for jump-starting a gay-rights movement. He became a leading voice of it.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: It Is Not the Homosexual Who Is Perverse, but the Society in Which He Lives (Movie)
item.media:credit: Ulrich Heinemann-Rufer/ullstein bild, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Rosa von Praunheim in 1972. He was a leading figure within the New German Cinema movement.

item.title: Venezuelan Opposition Leader Machado Will Publish a New Book
item.description: “The Freedom Manifesto,” by María Corina Machado, will lay out the Nobel laureate’s vision for a “new era,” its publisher said.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado, the Venezuelan opposition leader, will put out her proposals for a “new era” for Venezuela in a book next month.

item.title: Bela Tarr, Titan of Slow-Moving Cinema, Is Dead at 70
item.description: Called his “masterpiece,” one film, “Satantango,” is seven hours long. A favorite of critics and film festivals, he focused on the “human dignity” of marginal characters.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Bela Tarr in 2023. “I’m working for 30 years, and I’m doing the same movie,” he said. “About human dignity.”

item.title: Stephen Colbert Doubts Trump Can Run Two Countries at Once
item.description: “The Late Show” host said the president couldn’t possibly run two nations, because “he can’t even run.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Disney+, Amazon, HBO Max, Peacock and More in January
item.description: “The Pitt” Season 2, “Star Trek: Starfleet Academy,” “The Beauty,” “Wonder Man,” “Shrinking” Season 3 and more arrive.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray

item.title: The Most Anticipated Book Adaptations of 2026: Movies and TV Shows
item.description: “People We Meet on Vacation,” “Wuthering Heights” and “Project Hail Mary” are some of this year’s most anticipated adaptations.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Harlan

item.title: ‘The Pitt,’ Plus 10 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: The series, set in a Pittsburgh emergency room and starring Noah Wyle, returns. And a new group of players enter a castle in Scotland for “The Traitors.”
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Noah Wyle in “The Pitt.”

item.title: Robert Heide, Daring Playwright and Warhol Collaborator, Dies at 91
item.description: He helped create the Off Off Broadway theater scene, wrote and acted in Andy Warhol’s films, and turned his fascination with collectible Americana into books.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:credit: Billy Name Estate, via Dagon James
item.media:description: Mr. Heide in a photo from the 1960s.

item.title: Francis Patrelle, Champion of the Story Ballet, Dies at 78
item.description: Founding his own company, he built a tightly knit community in New York around his classes. His “Nutcracker,” set in the city in 1895, was his most popular production.
item.dc:creator: Marina Harss

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2: Behind the Scenes with Noah Wyle
item.description: Noah Wyle and his castmates turned one harrowing day at an E.R. into an unforgettable season of television. Can they do it again?
item.dc:creator: Sam Anderson
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson/Redux, for The New York Times
item.media:description: The actor Noah Wyle on the set of the HBO Max hospital drama “The Pitt.”

item.title: Julie Halston Sees Herself in Dorothy Parker
item.description: She stole the show in “And Just Like That …,” but theater is where the actress’s heart lies.
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Shattuck

item.title: Colossal Athletes Fill These Modern Arenas
item.description: Cosm, a company once focused on planetarium displays, is immersing sports fans with giant screens and desirable angles.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan and Jamie Lee Taete
item.media:description: Fans watching an N.B.A. game at Cosm in Inglewood, Calif., could hear the squeaking of sneakers and see the rim shaking after a dunk.

item.title: Angie Katsanevas Went From Real Housewives Outsider to the Center Snowflake
item.description: Angie Katsanevas has carved her own path through life, and her deadly quips on “The Real Housewives of Salt Lake City” have made her a breakout star.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Roy
item.category: The Real Housewives of Salt Lake City (TV Program)

item.title: Stephen Schwartz Criticizes Kennedy Center, Saying He Won’t Host Gala
item.description: The Washington National Opera said the “Wicked” composer was scheduled to host its annual event at the center this spring.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Adam Nagourney
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: “There’s no way I would set foot in it now,” Stephen Schwartz said of the Kennedy Center, which has seen many changes during the second Trump administration.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Pamela Colman Smith, Artist Behind a Famous Tarot Deck
item.description: She hand-painted around 80 illustrations for the Rider-Waite deck, which is still used around the world to predict destinies.
item.dc:creator: Emily Palmer

item.title: Violinist on Will Smith’s Tour Files Wrongful Termination Lawsuit
item.description: A lawyer for the musician, Brian King Joseph, says in the court papers that Mr. Joseph was fired after reporting sexual harassment.
item.dc:creator: Jason M. Bailey
item.media:description: Will Smith and his production company were accused in a lawsuit of wrongfully firing a violinist who performed on Mr. Smith’s “Based on a True Story” concert tour.

item.title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
item.description: A new year brings thrillers galore, with evil emerging from a pandemic, a summer camp and a rideshare app.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg
item.media:description: Jennifer Harlow in “No More Time.”

item.title: Gabriele Münter, an Overshadowed Pillar of Modern Art, Gets a Spotlight
item.description: “Contours of a World” at the Guggenheim Museum includes paintings as well as photography that suggests an alternate path.
item.dc:creator: Martha Schwendener

item.title: This Playwright Has Seen the Future. It Isn’t Human.
item.description: In “Marjorie Prime” and other works, Jordan Harrison delivers sweet-bitter anatomies of human connection mediated through technology destined to supersede us.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Despite the focus on technology in much of his work, Jordan Harrison has always been a late, or even non-adopter.

item.title: 9 European Exhibitions Worth Traveling For in 2026
item.description: With Björk, Parisian photography, and beauty and ugliness in the Renaissance, it’s shaping up to be an innovative year in art on the continent.
item.dc:creator: Emily LaBarge
item.category: Bozar, Center for Fine Arts (Brussels, Belgium)

item.title: Art Gallery Shows to See in January
item.description: This week in Newly Reviewed, Will Heinrich covers Jana Euler’s delightful absurdity, Lotty Rosenfeld’s portraits of the Pinochet dictatorship and Erich Heckel’s eerie dream world.
item.dc:creator: Will Heinrich
item.category: Wallach, Miriam and Ira D, Art Gallery

item.title: Janet Fish, Painter of Luminous Still Lifes, Dies at 87
item.description: From her student days, she stubbornly refused to follow popular artistic trends. Instead, she spent decades exploring the effects of light on glass.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: Review: The Met Opera Unveils ‘I Puritani’ on New Year’s Eve
item.description: Charles Edwards’s deceptively traditional, exceptionally sung production of Bellini’s “I Puritani” makes space for its stars.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone

item.title: ‘Stranger Things’ Has Ended. What Happened in the Series Finale?
item.description: There was a lot to tie up after five seasons and nearly 10 years, and the show gave itself another two hours to do it. Here are the major events.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.media:description: Eleven (Millie Bobby Brown, right, with Linnea Berthelsen) had a very difficult choice to make in the “Stranger Things” series finale.

item.title: He’s Chevy Chase, and He’s Still Like That
item.description: The famously prickly comedian found a sympathetic adversary in the director of a CNN documentary about him. Their conversation with a reporter was … spirited.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.category: I'm Chevy Chase and You're Not (Movie)
item.media:credit: Blaise Cepis for The New York Times
item.media:description: “He had looks and talent, and he had a chance,” Zenovich said of Chase, adding, “He made it as much as he could, but I think he turned to drugs and drinking to stop the pain.”

item.title: 24 Fun Things to Do in NYC in January 2026
item.description: Welcome to a new year. It promises Ian McKellen, fresh jazz, free exhibitions, restored films and comedy with latkes.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg
item.category: Skirball Center for the Performing Arts
What the Day Owes to the Night (Dance)

item.title: ‘We Bury the Dead’ Review: A Down Under Twist on the Zombie Flick
item.description: Daisy Ridley plays a woman who hopes her husband will spring back to life after a tragedy annihilates the population of Tasmania.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: ‘The Mother and the Bear’ Review: Dating for Her Daughter
item.description: This Korean Canadian soap opera is a moderately charming, if blandly earnest, drama about the dissonance and frictions between immigrant parents and their children
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: ‘The Dutchman’ Review: André Holland Is Lost in New York
item.description: The actor stars along side Kate Mara in a psychological thriller that goes deep into the Black Arts archives.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: 8 Things Our Critics Are Looking Forward to in 2026
item.description: Christopher Nolan goes (even more) epic, Lisa Kudrow makes another “Comeback” and Marcel Duchamp gets an overdue retrospective.
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter, Maya Phillips, James Poniewozik, Joshua Barone, Alissa Wilkinson, Mike Hale, Gia Kourlas and Jason Zinoman

item.title: ‘The Night Manager’ Season 2: Evoking John le Carré
item.description: After nearly a decade, a second season to the popular spy show is out this month. The showrunners explain how they created a sequel without a novel to draw from this time.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh
item.media:description: Tom Hiddleston in “The Night Manager.” The actor said of a conversation with John le Carré in 2016: “The man himself suggested, with a twinkle in his eye, that perhaps there might be a way to tell more of this story.”

item.title: For Some Nazi Loot, Value Is Measured on a Different Scale
item.description: Heirs of families that suffered in the Holocaust have gotten back precious items: not treasured art, but the keepsakes of dead relatives.
item.dc:creator: Milton Esterow and Michaela Towfighi

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in January
item.description: The first month of 2026 includes the latest Harlan Coben adaptation and the return of “Bridgerton.”
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.media:description: Yerin Ha in a scene from Part 1 of Season 4 of “Bridgerton.”

item.title: T Magazine’s Most-Read Art and Culture Features From 2025
item.description: A look at Japan’s microseasons, a retrospective on Gen X and more: These were readers’ 15 favorite stories.
item.dc:creator: T Magazine

item.title: Mohammad Bakri, Palestinian Whose Film Was Banned in Israel, Dies at 72
item.description: His 2002 documentary “Jenin, Jenin” exposed the often harsh realities of life experienced by his fellow Arabs in Israel.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: Richard Smallwood, 77, Choral Leader and Composer of Gospel Hits, Dies
item.description: He sold millions of albums with the Richard Smallwood Singers, and his songs, many influenced by classical music, were recorded by stars like Whitney Houston.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Richard Smallwood with his gospel chorus performing at the Hammerstein Ballroom in Manhattan in 2005. He wrote and arranged the group’s music, played piano and sang baritone.

item.title: Women Directed Fewer Box Office Hits in 2025, Report Finds
item.description: The number of female filmmakers dropped to 8.1 percent this year from 13.4 percent in 2024, according to a study from the University of Southern California.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi

item.title: The Top Movies of 2025, According to Times Readers: ‘Marty Supreme’ and More
item.description: We asked you to vote on the best films of the year. The results ranged from big box office hits to small art-house indies.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Goodman
item.category: Come See Me in the Good Light (Movie)
If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)
Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)

item.title: 6 Splendid Games You May Have Missed in 2025
item.description: Check out a beat-’em-up roguelite, a superhero corporate comedy and a museum simulator.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
